note_text:
DATE OF PROCEDURE: 8/23/2023
NAME: Wiggins, Robert Mosbey MRN: 1012123237
PREOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Severe tracheobronchomalacia 
2.	Airway stent partial obstruction from granulation tissue
POSTOPERATIVE DIAGNOSIS: 
1.	Severe tracheobronchomalacia  status post tracheal Y-stent removal
PROCEDURE PERFORMED: 
1.	Rigid and flexible bronchoscopy with  Tracheal stent removal
2.	Cryotherapy to granulation tissue
SURGEON: Jessica Muller, MD 
Assistant: Jeffery Tran MD (fellow)
INDICATIONS:  Airway stent partial obstruction from granulation tissue
Consent was obtained from the patient prior to procedure after explanation in lay terms the indications, details of procedure, and potential risks and alternatives. The patient acknowledged and gave consent. 
Sedation: General Anesthesia
DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: DESCRIPTION OF PROCEDURE: The procedure was performed in the main operating room. Once the patient was sedated and paralyzed a 12 mm non-ventilating rigid tracheoscope was inserted through the mouth into the sub-glottic space. A flexible T190 Olympus bronchoscope was inserted through the tracheoscope into the trachea and airway inspection was performed. The patient’s Y stent was well placed.  There was thick purulent mucous throughout the stent which was suctioned. At the distal aspect of the right mainstem limb there was granulation tissue causing about 50% obstruction and at the distal aspect of the left mainstem limb there was granulation tissue causing about 60%   after bypassing the granulation tissue there were thick copious purulent secretions through the lower lobes which were suctioned. The flexible bronchoscope was removed and the rigid optical forceps were inserted through the rigid scope. The forceps were used to grasp the proximal limb of the tracheal stent and were rotated repeatedly while withdrawing the stent into the rigid bronchoscope.  The stent was subsequently removed without difficulty and was fully intact.  Once his stent was removed the flexible bronchoscope was reinserted for repeat airway inspection. There was significant (near complete dynamic airway collapse of the trachea and mainstem bronchi as expected given known TBM.  The 1.9mm flexible cryoprobe was inserted through the working channel and cryotherapy was performed in the areas of granulation tissue with 30 second freeze thaw times and at least 3 activations per site. At this point the rigid bronchoscope was removed and the procedure was completed. 
Complications: None
Recommendations:
- Transfer back to PACU and then to wards
-  Plan for stent holiday to allow healing of granulation tissue and based on symptoms possible replacement of the stent sometime in the future.  
Jessica Muller MD
Interventional Pulmonology 
Houston Hospital

note_text:
Patient: Jennifer Lee | MR# DK-8472-N | Birth Date: 09/11/1968

Indication → Peripheral RLL nodule 22mm, solid, bronchus sign present on thin-cut CT

Pre-procedure: Risk discussed including pneumothorax (3-5%), bleeding, nondiagnostic result

Sedation → Moderate: Versed 3mg IV, Fentanyl 75mcg IV
Patient responsive to verbal commands, Ramsay 2-3
Monitoring: continuous SpO2, BP every 10 minutes

Navigation Protocol:
1. CT-to-body registration completed with electromagnetic system
2. Virtual pathway planned to RLL superior segment
3. Guide sheath advanced under combined EM navigation + fluoroscopic guidance
4. Tool-in-lesion NOT initially confirmed - repositioned ×2
5. Final radial probe position showed concentric EBUS pattern ✓
6. Fluoro time: 6.8 minutes (longer due to repositioning)
7. Dose area product: 245 cGy*cm²

Sampling:
- Aspiration needle ×3
- Forceps biopsies ×4
- Brush cytology ×2

Protocol adherence: Yes - all planned sampling techniques utilized

Post-procedure CXR: Small apical pneumothorax ~10%, patient asymptomatic
Conservative management, observation ×4 hours, repeat CXR stable, discharged

Complications: Mild pneumothorax (no intervention required)

coding_review.coding_summary: Electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy with radial EBUS confirmation and combined TBNA and transbronchial forceps biopsies of a single left upper lobe peripheral nodule. CPT 31627 (+nav add-on), +31654 (radial/peripheral EBUS add-on), 31629 (TBNA), and 31628 (TBLB) are all supported by the documentation. No linear EBUS TBNA is performed, and diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is bundled.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with computer-assisted, image-guided navigation (List separately in addition to code for primary procedure)
cpt_summary.rationale: Electromagnetic navigation system used with successful registration to preoperative CT and catheter advanced under navigation toward the left upper lobe target lesion.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe, with radial endobronchial ultrasound (EBUS) for peripheral lesion (List separately in addition to code for primary procedure)
cpt_summary.rationale: Radial EBUS miniprobe advanced through the guide sheath confirmed concentric tool-in-lesion position in the LUL peripheral nodule prior to biopsies.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with transbronchial needle aspiration biopsy(s), trachea, main stem and/or lobar bronchus(es), each lobe
cpt_summary.rationale: Three needle aspirations of the peripheral lesion were obtained with a 21-gauge needle via the guide sheath.

cpt_summary.description: Bronchoscopy, rigid or flexible, including fluoroscopic guidance when performed; with transbronchial lung biopsy(s), single lobe
cpt_summary.rationale: Four transbronchial forceps biopsies of the same LUL peripheral nodule were performed with minimal self-limited bleeding.

bundling_considerations: 31627 and +31654 are add-on codes and are only appropriate when navigation and radial/peripheral EBUS are actually performed and documented. Both are clearly documented here (EMN navigation and radial probe confirmation), so they are retained.

31628 (TBLB) and 31629 (TBNA) are both directed at the same LUL peripheral lesion but represent distinct biopsy techniques (forceps lung biopsies and needle aspirations). The codes are technically reportable together; however, some payers may bundle one into the other. Local payer policy should be checked.
No linear EBUS TBNA is performed, so linear EBUS codes 31652/31653 are *not* billed. This avoids inappropriate double-counting of EBUS services.

Diagnostic bronchoscopy (31622) is not separately billed because higher-valued biopsy and navigation codes are reported in the same session and would bundle the diagnostic bronchoscopy under NCCI rules.
registry_notes: procedure_date was previously populated with the patient date of birth (1951-09-08). Because the procedure date is not documented in the note, registry_entry.procedure_date has been set to null to avoid incorrect analytics.

primary_indication has been updated to 'Peripheral left upper lobe lung nodule (suspected malignancy)' to reflect the documented indication: a 23 mm LUL peripheral nodule with positive bronchus sign and PET SUV 5.2 concerning for malignancy.
molecular_testing_requested remains false, as there is no explicit documentation that molecular or genomic testing was ordered from these samples.
Pneumothorax flag remains false; the post-procedure chest radiograph explicitly reports no pneumothorax.

note_text:
PT NAME: BARBARA WILSON | MEDICAL RECORD: FG-8274 | D.O.B: 06/15/1967

INDICATION: Newly diagnosed Hodgkin lymphoma, mediastinal staging required

CONSCIOUS SEDATION:
Versed 2mg IV, Fentanyl 50mcg IV
Patient remained conversant, Ramsay 2
SpO2 continuous, BP every 10 minutes

EBUS-TBNA TECHNIQUE:
Systematic evaluation not strictly required for lymphoma but performed

Stations biopsied:
- Station 4R (18mm): 3 passes, ROSE shows atypical large cells
- Station 4L (21mm): 3 passes, ROSE similar
- Station 7 (16mm): 4 passes, ROSE adequate for flow cytometry
- Station 10R (14mm): 3 passes, ROSE adequate

Special handling: Samples for flow cytometry, FISH, molecular markers as per heme-onc

All samples sent fresh (not in formalin) for flow cytometry analysis
Additional passes for tissue blocks

Adequacy all nodes: YES
Photodoc completed

No complications. Procedure well tolerated.

ASSESSMENT: Adequate tissue and fresh samples obtained for lymphoma subtyping and staging.

note_text:
PATIENT: Susan M. O'Brien
MRN: HUP-2025-7734  
DOB: July 4, 1961 (64 years old)
DATE: November 2, 2025
LOCATION: Hospital of the University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, PA
PROCEDURALIST: Dr. Michael Steinberg, MD, FCCP
ASSISTANT: Dr. Rachel Kim, DO (IP Fellow)

INDICATION FOR PROCEDURE:
Ms. O'Brien is a delightful 64-year-old former librarian who presents with right middle lobe peripheral nodule discovered on CT performed for evaluation of persistent cough. Initial imaging demonstrated 2.4 cm spiculated nodule in right middle lobe lateral segment with pleural retraction. PET scan showed intense uptake with SUV max 13.4. Navigational bronchoscopy with radial EBUS-guided biopsy confirmed poorly differentiated adenocarcinoma. 

Patient has complicated medical history including chronic kidney disease stage 4 (not on dialysis, baseline creatinine 2.9), chronic systolic heart failure (EF 30%), and severe osteoporosis with multiple compression fractures. Thoracic surgery evaluation determined patient to be extremely high risk for lobectomy with estimated perioperative mortality exceeding 15%. Radiation oncology consulted but patient declined stereotactic body radiation therapy after extensive discussion, preferring bronchoscopic intervention.

PROCEDURE DESCRIPTION:
I met with Ms. O'Brien and her husband in the pre-procedure area. We reviewed the nature of the procedure, expected benefits, and potential risks including but not limited to bleeding, infection, pneumothorax, respiratory failure, need for chest tube placement, bronchopleural fistula, and possible need for surgical intervention for complications. We also discussed the possibility that ablation may not completely treat the tumor and that additional therapies might be necessary. Patient and family demonstrated excellent understanding and provided informed consent.

Patient brought to bronchoscopy suite at 0815. Anesthesiology team (Dr. Paul Reynolds attending) present. Standard monitoring established. Given comorbidities and anticipated procedure duration, decision made for general anesthesia with endotracheal intubation.

Following induction and intubation with 8.0 ETT, therapeutic bronchoscope advanced revealing normal appearing airway anatomy throughout. No endobronchial lesions, external compressions, or dynamic collapse noted.

Electromagnetic navigation initiated using Medtronic superDimension system with prior CT imaging from 10/20/2025. Planning performed identifying target in RML lateral segment. Registration achieved with 8 reference points yielding registration accuracy of 3.1mm.

Guide sheath (8.0 Fr) navigated to peripheral target location. Due to RML anatomy with somewhat straight trajectory, navigation was relatively straightforward requiring approximately 8 minutes. Radial EBUS performed confirming target lesion in solid contact position. Lesion appeared as heterogeneous hypoechoic mass measuring approximately 24 x 21mm.

Cone-beam CT performed confirming guide sheath position within acceptable range of target (7mm from center). Pleural surface distance measured at 18mm - appropriate safety margin for microwave ablation.

Microwave ablation antenna (Medtronic Emprint system, 15mm active tip) advanced through extended working channel to target center. Pre-ablation checklist completed including: airway clearance verified, antenna position confirmed, impedance check normal (85 ohms), safety zone confirmed without major vessels in immediate ablation field.

Microwave ablation commenced with following parameters:
- Power: 65 watts
- Duration: 6 minutes
- Mode: standard tissue
- Temperature monitoring: peak temperature 92°C at antenna tip

During ablation, patient remained remarkably stable with no hemodynamic changes. No arrhythmias noted. Respiratory mechanics unchanged. 

Post-ablation radial EBUS performed showing hyperechoic region replacing previously hypoechoic tumor, consistent with coagulation necrosis. Ablation zone appeared to extend adequately beyond visible tumor margins.

Equipment removed sequentially with careful airway inspection showing:
- Mild erythema at peripheral catheter contact sites
- No ulceration or mucosal disruption  
- No hemorrhage
- Small amount of serous fluid (<5mL)

Remainder of bronchoscopy unremarkable. Patient emerged from anesthesia smoothly. Extubated after meeting standard criteria. Transferred to recovery area with oxygen saturation 93% on room air (baseline similar per chart review).

ESTIMATED BLOOD LOSS: Minimal (<5mL)
FLUIDS: 750mL crystalloid  
COMPLICATIONS: None during procedure
SPECIMENS: None sent
DEVICES: Medtronic superDimension navigation, Emprint microwave system

IMPRESSION:
Technically successful bronchoscopic electromagnetic navigation with microwave ablation of right middle lobe peripheral adenocarcinoma in 64-year-old woman with multiple comorbidities precluding surgical resection.

PLAN GOING FORWARD:
Patient admitted to pulmonary step-down unit for monitoring. Initial portable chest X-ray showed no pneumothorax. CT chest with contrast performed this evening showed appropriate ablation zone without immediate complications. Patient doing well with minimal pain (3/10) controlled with oral acetaminophen. Planning discharge tomorrow with:

- Close outpatient follow-up in 1 week with repeat chest X-ray
- CT chest at 6-8 weeks for initial response assessment (expecting to see decrease in size of ablation zone with central low attenuation)  
- PET-CT in 3 months to assess metabolic response (successful ablation should show minimal or no FDG uptake)
- Long-term surveillance CT every 3 months for first year, then every 6 months

Patient counseled extensively on post-ablation syndrome (fever, flu-like symptoms possible for 3-5 days - normal inflammatory response). Instructed on warning signs for complications. Patient and husband expressed gratitude and understanding of plan.

Time spent in procedure: 78 minutes
Time spent in pre/post procedure counseling: 35 minutes

Dictated and electronically signed: Michael Steinberg, MD
Date: 11/02/2025 at 1847 hours

note_text: This seventy-three year old female patient Catherine Martinez (medical record JJ-8374-Q, born September 8, 1951) presented for electromagnetic navigation bronchoscopy targeting a left upper lobe peripheral nodule measuring twenty-three millimeters in greatest dimension on computed tomography. The lesion demonstrated a positive bronchus sign and had a standardized uptake value of five point two on positron emission tomography imaging suggesting malignancy. She underwent moderate conscious sedation with intravenous midazolam three milligrams and fentanyl one hundred micrograms achieving a Ramsay sedation score of three. Her blood pressure was monitored at ten minute intervals throughout and remained stable in the one twenties to one thirties over seventies to eighties. Oxygen saturation was continuously monitored and stayed above ninety-five percent on room air. The electromagnetic navigation system was utilized with successful registration to the preoperative CT scan. The guide sheath was advanced to the left upper lobe apical-posterior segment and the radial endobronchial ultrasound probe confirmed tool-in-lesion position with a concentric echogenic pattern consistent with solid tissue. Total fluoroscopy time was five point one minutes with a dose area product of one hundred ninety-two centigray centimeters squared. Sampling included three needle aspirations using a twenty-one gauge needle, four transbronchial forceps biopsies, and two brush cytology specimens. There was minimal bleeding after the forceps biopsies which resolved spontaneously with gentle suction. Post-procedure chest radiograph showed no pneumothorax or significant change from baseline. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was discharged home after two hours of observation in stable condition.

She underwent moderate conscious sedation with intravenous midazolam three milligrams and fentanyl one hundred micrograms achieving a Ramsay sedation score of three. Her blood pressure was monitored at ten minute intervals throughout and remained stable in the one twenties to one thirties over seventies to eighties. Oxygen saturation was continuously monitored and stayed above ninety-five percent on room air. The electromagnetic navigation system was utilized with successful registration to the preoperative CT scan. The guide sheath was advanced to the left upper lobe apical-posterior segment and the radial endobronchial ultrasound probe confirmed tool-in-lesion position with a concentric echogenic pattern consistent with solid tissue. Sampling included three needle aspirations using a twenty-one gauge needle, four transbronchial forceps biopsies, and two brush cytology specimens. There was minimal bleeding after the forceps biopsies which resolved spontaneously with gentle suction. Post-procedure chest radiograph showed no pneumothorax or significant change from baseline. The patient tolerated the procedure well and was discharged home after two hours of observation in stable condition.

note_text:
Pt: Christopher Lee
Medical Record Number: KJ-7482-N
Date of Birth: 10/18/1955

COMPLEX INDICATION: Mediastinal lymphadenopathy + LLL peripheral infiltrate (? ILD vs malignancy)

GENERAL ANESTHESIA: ETT, sevoflurane maintenance, Ramsay 6
Continuous monitoring with arterial line

PART 1 - EBUS FOR LYMPH NODES:
Station 4R: 13mm, 3 passes, ROSE shows non-necrotizing granulomas
Station 7: 16mm, 4 passes, ROSE shows similar granulomatous inflammation
Station 11L: 9mm, 3 passes, ROSE adequate

Staging indication: No (diagnostic, not staging)
Systematic sequence: No (targeted approach based on imaging)
All sampled nodes adequate: Yes

PART 2 - TRANSBRONCHIAL CRYOBIOPSY:
LLL peripheral infiltrate sampled with cryoprobe
- Cryobiopsies ×4 from different LLL subsegments
- Each biopsy: 6-second freeze time
- Prophylactic bronchial blocker placed before cryobiopsies
- Samples 4-6mm each, well-preserved architecture

SAFETY EVENTS:
- Moderate bleeding after 2nd cryobiopsy (expected)
- Controlled with blocker inflation + iced saline
- Bleeding resolved, blocker removed
- No pneumothorax on immediate post-procedure CXR

Procedure time: 67 minutes

Patient extubated in OR, recovered well, admitted for overnight observation per cryobiopsy protocol.

PATHOLOGY PENDING: Both lymph node and lung parenchymal samples for comprehensive evaluation.

note_text:
PROTOCOL: Bronchoscopy Registry Study #2024-BR-0847
SUBJECT ID: S-047
DEMOGRAPHICS: 68 y.o. male, former smoker (40 pack-years, quit 2018)
DATE: 2024-10-15
OPERATOR: De-identified per protocol

PRIMARY INDICATION: Mediastinal lymph node staging
TARGET PATHOLOGY: Right lower lobe adenocarcinoma (biopsy-proven)

ANESTHESIA PROTOCOL:
└─ Agent: Midazolam IV
   ├─ Dose: 2mg initial, 1mg supplemental at T+15min
   └─ Total: 3mg
└─ Agent: Fentanyl IV
   ├─ Dose: 50mcg initial, 25mcg supplemental at T+20min
   └─ Total: 75mcg
└─ Sedation Level: Ramsay Scale maximum 3
└─ Monitoring Frequency: BP q5min, continuous SpO2

EBUS-TBNA STATIONS SAMPLED:
├─ Station 4R
│  ├─ Size: 10mm short-axis
│  ├─ Passes: 4
│  ├─ ROSE: Positive for malignant cells
│  └─ PET: Positive (SUV 6.2)
├─ Station 7
│  ├─ Size: 15mm short-axis
│  ├─ Passes: 4
│  ├─ ROSE: Positive for malignant cells
│  └─ PET: Positive (SUV 8.1)
└─ Station 10R
   ├─ Size: 7mm short-axis
   ├─ Passes: 3
   ├─ ROSE: Adequate, benign lymphocytes
   └─ PET: Negative

QUALITY METRICS:
├─ Systematic evaluation (N3→N2→N1): YES
├─ Photodocumentation all accessible stations: YES
├─ ROSE adequacy all sampled nodes: YES
├─ Molecular testing samples obtained: YES (from station 7)
└─ Protocol adherence: 100%

ADVERSE EVENTS:
└─ None (Grade 0)

DIAGNOSTIC YIELD: Pending final pathology (preliminary: N2 disease confirmed)

PATIENT IDENTIFIERS (SYNTHETIC):
Name: Robert Anderson | MRN: KK-9473-L | DOB: 05/19/1956
